issues.text: Whether an appeal lies under section 19(1) of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971 against the refusal of the High Court to initiate contempt proceedings on a motion made by any person

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor General contended that no appeal lay under section 19, sub-section 1 against the refusal of the High Court to take action on the motion made by the appellant. It is, only if the High Court suo motu or on a motion made by the Advocate General or any other person with the consent in writing of the Advocate General takes action and initiates proceeding for contempt against the alleged contemner and on arriving at a finding of guilt, punishes him for contempt that the alleged contemner has a right of appeal under section 19, sub-section 1. Even if a proceeding for contempt is initiated against the alleged contemner but the alleged contemner is found not guilty and is exonerated, there is no right of appeal, contended the learned Additional Solicitor General, and neither the Advocate General nor the person who has, with the consent in writing of the Advocate General, moved the High Court, can appeal as of right. The appellant, who appeared in person, combated this contention by relying on the words any order or decision in the exercise of its jurisdiction to punish for contempt and urged that even if a decision was taken by the High Court not to take action on the motion made by the Advocate General or any other person with the consent in writing of the Advocate General, it would still be a decision in the exercise of its jurisdiction to punish for contempt and would, therefore, be appealable on the plain terms of section 19, sub-section 1.

issues.text: Whether an appeal under section 19(1) lies where the High Court initiates contempt proceedings but finds the alleged contemner not guilty, exonerates him, or declines to punish even if guilty

anchor.surface_text: We may point out that in the present case it is unnecessary to consider whether an appeal under section 19, subsection 1 is confined only to a case where the High Court after initiating a proceeding for contempt finds the alleged contemner guilty and punishes him for contempt as contended by the learned Additional Solicitor General or it extends also to a case where after initiating a proceeding for contempt, the High Court finds that the alleged contemner is not guilty of contempt and exonerates him, or even if he is found guilty of contempt, declines to punish him.

arguments.claim: No appeal lies under section 19(1) of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971 against the High Court's refusal to initiate contempt proceedings on a motion made by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal reached hearing before us, the learned Additional Solicitor General, appearing on behalf of the respondent, raised a preliminary objection against the maintainability of the appeal. The learned Additional Solicitor General contended that no appeal lay under section 19, sub-section  1  against the refusal

arguments.court_reasoning: Jurisdiction to punish commences only on initiation of proceedings; refusal is discretionary pre-jurisdictional decision.

arguments.claim: Criminal contempt jurisdiction is entirely between court and alleged contemnor; no third-party right to compel initiation or punishment; court discretion absolute even if prima facie contempt.

anchor.surface_text: It has always been regarded as well settled law that so far as criminal contempt is concerned, it is a matter entirely between the Court and the alleged contemner. No one has a statutory or common law right to say that he is entitled as a

arguments.claim: Pre-Contempt Act 1971, no appeal lay against High Court refusal to initiate contempt or against punishment orders except via discretionary Art.134 certificate or Art.136 SLP.

anchor.surface_text: It was for this reason that a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court held in Narendrabhai Sarabhai Hatheesing v. Chinubhai Manibhai, Seth 1  that an order made by the High Court refusing to commit a man for breach of an undertaking

arguments.claim: Sanyal Committee criticized lack of appeal rights in contempt; recommended as-of-right appeals from punishment orders, leading to enactment of s.19(1).

anchor.surface_text: This unsatisfactory feature of the law of contempt was adversely commented upon by Sanyal Committee in its Report dated 28th February, 1963 submitted to the Government of India. The Sanyal Committee, pointed out in Paragraph 2.1

arguments.claim: Under ss.15,17,20, court enters contempt jurisdiction only upon deciding to initiate proceedings; motion/reference merely draws attention, refusal not exercise of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Before we examine the language of section 19, sub-section  1  in order to arrive at its true interpretation, we may first look at sections 15, 17 and 20. Sub-section  1  of section 15 provides that in a case of criminal contempt

arguments.court_reasoning: No contempt; lacked AG consent under s15(4).

holdings.text: No appeal lies under section 19(1) of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971 against a decision of the High Court declining to initiate proceedings for contempt on a motion or reference.

anchor.surface_text: Where the Court rejects a motion or a reference and declines to initiate a proceeding for contempt, it refuses to assume or exercise jurisdiction to punish for contempt and such a decision cannot be regarded as a decision in the exercise of its jurisdiction to punish for contempt. Such a decision would not, therefore, fall within the opening words of section 19, sub-section 1 and no appeal would lie against it as of right under that provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.15,17,20 shows jurisdiction commences on initiation via notice; pre-initiation refusal is discretionary non-jurisdictional; aligns with pre-1971 law lacking appeals against refusals and Sanyal Committee's focus on punishment appeals.

holdings.text: The exercise of jurisdiction to punish for criminal contempt commences only when the court decides to take action and initiates a proceeding for contempt.

anchor.surface_text: It is only when the Court decides to take action and initiates a proceeding for contempt that it assumes jurisdiction to punish for contempt. The exercise of the jurisdiction to punish for contempt commence with the initiation of a proceeding for contempt, whether suo motu or on a motion or a reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Motion/reference merely draws attention; court discretion to initiate or decline even if prima facie contempt; limitation under s.20 runs from initiation confirming jurisdictional start.

holdings.text: The present appeal against the Orissa High Court's order dated 13th February 1973 refusing to initiate contempt proceedings is not maintainable under section 19(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore. clear that the order made by the Full Bench of the Orissa High Court in the present case rejecting the motion made by the appellant and refusing to initiate a proceeding for contempt against the Chief Justice and other judges was not appealable under section 19, sub-section 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of general principle to facts: High Court rejected motion without initiating proceedings.

holdings.text: Against a High Court order refusing to initiate contempt proceedings, though no appeal lies under s.19(1), special leave petition under Article 136 is available.

anchor.surface_text: This of course does not mean that there is no remedy available where the High Court on an erroneous view of the law or unreasonably and perversely refuses to take action for contempt on a motion or a reference. Though no appeal lies under section 19, sub-section 1 as of right against such order or decisions of the High Court, the Advocate General or any other person who has with the consent in writing of the Advocate General moved the High Court can always come to this Court by a petition for special leave to appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extraordinary jurisdiction under Art.136 unfettered to correct errors in larger interest of justice.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether appeal under s.19(1) lies where High Court initiates proceedings but acquits contemnor or declines to punish.

anchor.surface_text: We may point out that in the present case it is unnecessary to consider whether an appeal under section 19, subsection 1 is confined only to a case where the High Court after initiating a proceeding for contempt finds the alleged contemner guilty and punishes him for contempt as contended by the learned Additional Solicitor General or it extends also to a case where after initiating a proceeding for contempt, the High Court finds that the alleged contemner is not guilty of contempt and exonerates him, or even if he is found guilty of contempt, declines to punish him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue does not arise on facts as no proceedings initiated.

precedents.citation: Narendrabhai Sarabhai Hatheesing v. Chinubhai Manibhai, Seth I.L.R. 60 Bom. 894

anchor.surface_text: a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court held in Narendrabhai Sarabhai Hatheesing v. Chinubhai Manibhai, Seth 1  that an order made by the High Court refusing to committal a man for breach of an undertaking given to the Court is number a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent as it does number affect the merits of any question between the parties to the suit. Beaumont, C.J., pointed out the undertaking is given to the Court if it is broken, and that fact is brought to the Courts numberice, the Court may take such action as it thinks fit. If it comes to the conclusion that the order has been deliberately broken, it will probably commit the defaulter to jail, but the Court is free to adopt such course as it thinks fit. Rangnekar, J., also spoke in the same strain when he said Proceedings for contempt are matters entirely between the Court and the person alleged to have been guilty of contempt. No party has any statutory right to say that he is entitled as a matter of course to an order for committal because his opponent is guilty of contempt. All that he can do is to come to the Court and complain that the authority of the Court has been flouted, and if the Court thinks that it was so, then the Court in its discretion takes action to vindicate its authority. It is, therefore, difficult to see how an application for contempt raises any question between the parties, so that any order made I.L.R. 60 Bom. 894. on such an application by which the Court in its discretion refuses to take any action against the party alleged to be in the wrong can be said to raise any question between the parties.

precedents.case_name: Narendrabhai Sarabhai Hatheesing v. Chinubhai Manibhai Seth
precedents.cited_proposition: an order made by the High Court refusing to commit a man for breach of an undertaking given to the Court is not a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent as it does not affect the merits of any question between the parties to the suit
precedents.cited_holding: Proceedings for contempt are matters entirely between the Court and the person alleged to have been guilty of contempt. No party has any statutory right to say that he is entitled as a matter of course to an order for committal because his opponent is guilty of contempt.

anchor.surface_text: Where the Court rejects a motion or a reference and declines to initiate a proceeding for contempt, it refuses to assume or exercise jurisdiction to punish for contempt and such a decision cannot be regarded as a decision in the exercise of its jurisdiction to punish for contempt. Such a decision would not, therefore, fall within the opening words of section 19, sub-section 1 and no appeal would lie against it as of right under that provision.

anchor.surface_text: It is only when the Court decides to take action and initiates a proceeding for contempt that it assumes jurisdiction to punish for contempt. The exercise of the jurisdiction to punish for contempt commence with the initiation of a proceeding for contempt, whether suo motu or on a motion or a reference.

We are, therefore, of the view that the preliminary objection raised by the respondent is well founded and the appellant is number entitled to maintain the present appeal under section-19, sub-section  1

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore. clear that the order made by the Full Bench of the Orissa High Court in the present case rejecting the motion made by the appellant and refusing to initiate a proceeding for contempt against the Chief Justice and other judges was not appealable under section 19, sub-section 1.

We are, therefore, of the view that the preliminary objection raised by the respondent is well founded and the appellant is number entitled to maintain the present appeal under section-19, sub-section  1

anchor.surface_text: We may point out that in the present case it is unnecessary to consider whether an appeal under section 19, subsection 1 is confined only to a case where the High Court after initiating a proceeding for contempt finds the alleged contemner guilty and punishes him for contempt as contended by the learned Additional Solicitor General or it extends also to a case where after initiating a proceeding for contempt, the High Court finds that the alleged contemner is not guilty of contempt and exonerates him, or even if he is found guilty of contempt, declines to punish him.
